snippet: The nightclub shooting in Orlando, Fla., has focused unusual attention on the mundane process of investigating thousands of people accused of terrorist ties.
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation's decision to close counterterrorism investigation of Orlando shooter Omar Mateen prior to rampage has focused attention on mundane but closely-considered process; at issue is how to improve efficacy of system involving several thousand agents working on up to 10,000  terrorism cases at time, sorting legitimate from bogus tips and threats; prospect of 'lone-wolf' cases like Mateen's has made process much more difficult.

byline.original: By MATT APUZZO and ERIC LICHTBLAU
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Eric Schmitt from Washington, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Marc Santora from New York, and Carol Pogash from Rodeo, Calif.

lead_paragraph: The nightclub shooting in Orlando, Fla., has focused unusual attention on the mundane process of investigating thousands of people accused of terrorist ties.

headline.main: After F.B.I.’s Inquiry Into Omar Mateen, a Focus on What Else Could Be Done
headline.print_headline: After F.B.I.’s Inquiry, a Focus on What Else Could Be Done
